nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates of economic damages from climate change substantially underestimate true risks and should be rejected for policy use; in particular, the influential DICE integrated assessment model is incapable of producing economic collapse regardless of damage severity
Scientific literature establishes multiple climate tipping points and tipping cascades that could be triggered this century and amplify global warming and impacts
Nordhaus and many economic studies misrepresented or ignored the scientific tipping-point literature when justifying quadratic damage functions that omit thresholds

A common methodological assumption in economic damage estimates is that only activities directly exposed to weather are affected by climate change, leading to omission of manufacturing, services, government and other major sectors

Another common method uses spatial (cross-sectional) correlations between current temperature and income as proxies for temporal global warming impacts, implicitly assuming spatial relationships hold over time

Other methodological choices include reliance on small expert elicitations biased toward economists, computable general equilibrium (CGE) approaches that assume welfare-maximizing adaptation, and shared calibration data across IAMs (DICE, FUND, PAGE)

DICE model structure: Ramsey growth core with Cobb-Douglas production, exogenous labor and TFP, damages as fractional reduction of output, and abatement costs reducing available output; emissions control chosen via carbon price/backstop tradeoff

Evidence from tipping-point expert assessments and scientific studies identifies near-term thresholds (e.g., Arctic sea-ice, Greenland ice sheet) and the risk of cascading interactions that economists downplayed or excluded

Nordhaus cited Lenton et al. selectively to justify omitting tipping points and used a quadratic damage function D(delta T)=a*(delta T)^2 calibrated to trivial global GDP losses (e.g., 2.1% at 3C, 7.9% at 6C)

Three rebuttals to the 'exposed-only' assumption: (a) extreme events (fires, floods) damage indoor facilities and supply chains; (b) heat and wet-bulb lethal conditions can make workplaces uninhabitable; (c) environmental inputs (energy, resources, biodiversity) are essential to production and will be affected

Evidence and examples: studies showing lethal wet-bulb thresholds for humans at ~35C, projected loss of livable area at multi-degree warming, and impacts on energy grids and agriculture that would disrupt manufacturing and services

Statistical cross-sectional fits of temperature to regional GDP explain little variance and ignore trade, historic adaptation, soil/topsoil constraints, and that future global mean changes introduce novel climates and extremes not represented in current spatial patterns
Shared data and model calibration: many IAMs and policy SCC estimates are calibrated to the same limited, flawed empirical studies, propagating underestimation across policy-relevant models

Mathematical property of the Ramsey core used in DICE: saddle-path stability requires instantaneous jumps of a 'jump' variable (consumption per capita) to remain on the unique stable path, an assumption that imposes extreme informational and adjustment capabilities

DICE implausible resilience result: sensitivity experiments increasing damage coefficient produce scenarios where damages exceed 90% of GDP yet the model yields recovery (via corner solutions of full mitigation, extreme carbon prices, unrealistically low capital-output ratios and continued exogenous productivity), and only when damages exceed a threshold does the solver fail rather than produce collapse

Conclusion: Because economic empirical methods systematically ignore tipping points, misapply spatial proxies, omit whole sectors, and because DICE's mathematical structure cannot generate collapse, economists' low damage estimates and IAMs calibrated to them are unscientific and unsuitable for evaluating climate risks or informing policy
